class_f_06_dragon_01: Hello, class! It is I, Hassel, yet again.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_02:
First, allow me to apologize for losing my
composure during our last class...[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_03:
I was so touched by Brassius’s story that I simply
couldn’t contain my emotions. I’m sorry for\r
making such a scene.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_04:
I certainly got a very stern talking-to from
Ms. Tyme after that class, yes...[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_05:
Anyway, let us shift gears and dive into the
material for today’s class![npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_06:
Now, have any of you heard of the Ten Sights
of Paldea?[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_07:
As the name would imply, they are ten sights in
Paldea that are considered particularly beautiful.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_08:
Among them, I would say that the[clr:6] Grand Olive[clr:0]
[clr:6]Orchard[clr:0] is likely the most accessible.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_09:
You can see field after field of olive trees from
the hill on the way to Cortondo.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_10:
Two waterfalls are also counted among these
ten sights—[clr:6]Fury Falls[clr:0] and [clr:6]Casseroya Falls[clr:0].[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_11:
Then there’s the peak of Glaseado Mountain,
known as [clr:6]Paldea’s Highest Peak[clr:0].[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_12:
There’s another cliff on Glaseado Mountain that’s
named after its rather unique shape.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_13: So, let me ask you, my students![npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_14:
What is the name of the three-pronged cliff on
Glaseado Mountain? No need to grasp at straws![npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_answer_01:
[BD06:0]Exactly! It looks like a hand taking hold of
something, doesn’t it, [trnm:0]?[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_answer_02:
A very good guess! I’d think something reaching
would stretch out farther, though.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_answer_03:
A unique take! But that sort of name would
usually apply to a slope, don’t you think?[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_15:
The three-pronged cliff on Glaseado Mountain
is in fact known as [clr:6]Glaseado’s Grasp[clr:0].[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_16:
Though its shape is far too stubby to be that
of a human hand. I imagine someone thought it\r
looked like a Pokémon hand grabbing something.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_17:
There’s also the mountains in Area Three of the
East Province, where you can get a good look at\r
Levincia. It’s particularly gorgeous at night![npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_18:
In fact, the view is so brilliant, it is known as the
[clr:6]Million Volt Skyline[clr:0].[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_19:
I hear it’s quite a hotspot for dates—and
deservedly so for having such a romantic view![npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_20:
I imagine it’s...what do the kids say these days...
a very, ahem, “fleek selfie spot”?[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_21:
Of course, you may feel that not all ten sights live
up to their grandiose names. How often do we\r
visit some tourist spot only to be disappointed?[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_22:
Not to say that you shouldn’t visit them, only
that you should keep your hopes in check.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_23:
The important thing is to go yourself and see
them with your own two eyes.[npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_24:
And sometimes, a disappointing experience can
be worthwhile in its own way. Take a chance![npcn:12]
class_f_06_dragon_25:
Well, that’s it for today, class. Thank you for
your attention![npcn:12]
